abstract.text: A style’s fog property is a global effect that improves depth perception by fading out distant objects.

An array of two number values, specifying the vertical range, measured in meters, over which the fog should gradually fade out. When both parameters are set to zero, the fog will be rendered without any vertical constraints.
Supported light types
The name of the projection to be used for rendering the map.

will show no stars and
will show stars at their maximum intensity.

Defines the available light presets in the Mapbox Standard Style.

An array of two number values, specifying the vertical range, measured in meters, over which the fog should gradually fade out. When both parameters are set to zero, the fog will be rendered without any vertical constraints.
A light that has a direction and is located at infinite distance, so its rays are parallel. It simulates the sun light and can cast shadows.
Information about a light
The color of the region above the horizon and after the end of the
contribution. The opacity can be set to
to have a transparent background.
Transition property for

Horizon blend applies a smooth fade from the color of the atmosphere to the color of space. A value of zero leaves a sharp transition from atmosphere to space. Increasing the value blends the color of atmosphere into increasingly high angles of the sky.
The color of the atmosphere region immediately below the horizon and within the
and above the horizon and within
. Using opacity is recommended only for smoothly transitioning fog on/off as anything less than 100% opacity results in more tiles loaded and drawn.

The start and end distance range in which fog fades from fully transparent to fully opaque. The distance to the point at the center of the map is defined as zero, so that negative range values are closer to the camera, and positive values are farther away.

The
control timing for the interpolation between a transitionable style
property’s previous value and new value. These can be used to define the style default property
transition behavior. Also, any transitionable style property may also have its own
property that defines specific transition timing for that specific layer property, overriding
the global transition values.

An indirect light affecting all objects in the map adding a constant amount of light on them. It has no explicit direction and cannot cast shadows.
